player_decision.reason: Open-raise to 30 (3bb) with pocket sixes to build the pot and isolate the blinds. Raising is more profitable than calling here and maintains aggression to maximize chip accumulation toward winning the tournament.

With As6d facing a 30 bet in a 3-handed pot, calling 25 to see the flop gives reasonable pot odds (pot would be 70 after call) and reasonable equity versus a wide opponent range. Folding costs the 5 already invested, and a raise is too thin with a marginal ace and potential dominated outs.
6-3 offsuit plays terribly out of position. With ~10BB effective facing a raise and a call, calling commits us with a dominated hand and jamming is too weak. Preserve chips and fold.

On Ts 2d 3s with As6d you have only Ace-high and a rare backdoor straight (A-2-3-4-5) requiring running 4 and 5 in either order. Equity is extremely thin (~1–2%), and the flop bet isn’t favorable for a raise. Since folding isn’t offered here, calling to see the turn is the least wasteful option to try to realize any runner-runner equity.
With pocket sixes on a dry 10-3-2 flop, bet for value and protection. Half-pot sizing puts pressure on draws and worse pairs while keeping stacks manageable to win the current pot.

Ace-high on a T- high flop with no real outs. Villain’s flop bet (40 into ~110) leaves you with very thin equity (only backdoor straight/flush possibilities). Calling or shoving is too costly for marginal improvement. Fold to preserve your stack for better spots.
